title: Sometimes in the Bible it says Jesus Christ. But sometimes it says Christ Jesus. What is the difference? - Quora

response.answer_text: No difference at all. The word ‘Christ’ is the Greek version of the Hebrew word, ‘Messiah’, which means ‘Anointed one’. Properly spoken or written, it is ‘The Christ’ but English typically drops the definitive (‘The/our/your/…’) when speaking of a single directly identifiable entity (Like saying ‘Jehovah [the/our/your] GOD’) The word ‘Christ’ is a title and identifier and can be used before or after the pronoun (personal name): like ‘Sailor Sam’ and ‘Sam the Sailor’ (remember that properly, it is ‘Jesus THE Christ’) See also, John THE BAPTIST. His family name was ‘Baptist’… it was the title of his vocation (a Baptiser). In an corrective, also, Jesus should never be called ‘God the Son’ as ‘God’ was never a ‘Son’ (Nor indeed was ‘God’ ever a ‘Holy Spirit’. There is ONLY ONE GOD and that is ‘The Father’ (which means: ‘Creator, he that brings forth, brings into being, the Head’). If ‘the Father’ brought forth ‘the Son’, how can ‘the Son’ be ‘God’?

There’ll be some difference, forensically analyzed. I think such differences are important to people who differentiate themselves and boost their appearances in little ponds. The communication is equal, usually, for both word-sequences. There’s a truth in those words relative to prophets and reality. I believe in Jesus as a person to be at one with as we all are with each other independent of time. All great leaders are prophets who unify people with each other and all true prophets. Differences of description/name relate to humans trying to hijack local natural spiritual beliefs about the meanings of words like “prophet” and “christ” and “jesus” and any other sacred names. Conventions, within bovine male-dominant social-political clubs, impose obedience to leaders who elevate themselves into dominance then enforce their views about differences. Parasites and predators tend to pose as kind leaders yet they act as if they presume they are more important than those they pretend to care for. Such fake leaders trick other people into being subservient enough to kill other people for the short-term benefit of… parasites and predators. The most powerful aspect of the trick is to falsely interpret the words of prophets then impose those interpretations as legal and deadly rules for other people. Some may refer to a person who has been “christed” and others may refer to a person as a superstar “christ” example of a human being. Others may refer to a person who is real in multi-dimensional space and time and who is one with all prophets and who is liked to all of us. We are all part of the same person. Some say a particular person is the “son of …” as if being loved by and at one with … is different for a particular prophet. My answer (re the question above) relates to loving unity led by people who’ve got close enough to unity as to be say “Christed” which is is our birthright as exemplified by our prophets. There’s a peculiar aspect of how spirituality is talked abou. The differences between the order of even two words can cause millions of deaths . An invention of an ancient empire tried to unify the empire using religious rules and punishments related to spirituality. The techniques took thousands of years to mature and, now, the habits of thinking about word-differences command wars. Slight differences, between various noises and sequences of noises, are exploited by mediocre people who purport to be leaders and, in their own mind are leaders. Such parasites are often predators purporting to have exclusive interpretations of abstract spiritual beliefs which are common to all of life. The difference between the word sequences as in/and “what is the difference” (above) is too large for me to get into historical details which other people know about but for which I have no energy nor time to spend on that sort of information. My view of the question is that it refers to the whole deal about people killing each other because of words about spirituality.
